div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: An apartment in the DUKE'S palace.
Enter DUKE, ESCALUS, Lords and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Escalus.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Of government the properties to unfold,
Would seem in me to affect speech and discourse;
Since I am put to know that your own science
Exceeds, in that, the lists of all advice
My strength can give you: then no more remains,
But that to your sufficiency........
....................as your worth is able,
And let them work. The nature of our people,
Our city's institutions, and the terms
For common justice, you're as pregnant in
As art and practice hath enriched any
That we remember. There is our commission,
From which we would not have you warp. Call hither,

I say, bid come before us Angelo.
[Exit an Attendant.
What figure of us think you he will bear?
For you must know, we have with special soul
Elected him our absence to supply,
Lent him our terror, dress'd him with our love,
And given his deputation all the organs
Of our own power: what think you of it?

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: If any in Vienna be of worth
To undergo such ample grace and honour,
It is Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
Look where he comes.
Enter ANGELO.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Always obedient to your grace's will,
I come to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Angelo,
There is a kind of character in thy life,
That to the observer doth thy history
Fully unfold. Thyself and thy belongings
Are not thine own so proper as to waste
Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee.
Heaven doth with us as we with torches do,
Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues
Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike
As if we had them not. Spirits are not finely touch'd
But to fine issues, nor Nature never lends
The smallest scruple of her excellence
But, like a thrifty goddess, she determines
Herself the glory of a creditor,
Both thanks and use. But I do bend my speech
To one that can my part in him advertise;
Hold therefore, Angelo:--
In our remove be thou at full ourself;
Mortality and mercy in Vienna
Live in thy tongue and heart: old Escalus,
Though first in question, is thy secondary.
Take thy commission.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now, good my lord,
Let there be some more test made of my metal,
Before so noble and so great a figure
Be stamp'd upon it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No more evasion:
We have with a leaven'd and prepared choice
Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours.
Our haste from hence is of so quick condition
That it prefers itself and leaves unquestion'd
Matters of needful value. We shall write to you,
As time and our concernings shall importune,
How it goes with us, and do look to know
What doth befall you here. So, fare you well:
To the hopeful execution do I leave you
Of your commissions.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yet give leave, my lord,
That we may bring you something on the way.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My haste may not admit it;
Nor need you, on mine honour, have to do
With any scruple; your scope is as mine own,
So to enforce or qualify the laws
As to your soul seems good. Give me your hand:
I'll privily away. I love the people,
But do not like to stage me to their eyes:
Though it do well, I do not relish well
Their loud applause and Aves vehement;
Nor do I think the man of safe discretion
That does affect it. Once more, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The heavens give safety to your purposes!

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l:
Lead forth and bring you back in
happiness!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
I thank you. Fare you well.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: I shall desire you, sir, to give me leave
To have free speech with you; and it concerns me
To look into the bottom of my place:
A power I have, but of what strength and nature
I am not yet instructed.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together,
And we may soon our satisfaction have
Touching that point.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l:
I'll wait upon your honour.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
If the duke with the other dukes come
not to
composition with the King of Hungary,
why then all the
dukes fall upon the king.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
Heaven grant us its peace, but
not the King
of Hungary's!

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Thou concludest like the sanctimonious
pirate,
that went to sea with the Ten
Commandments, but
scraped one out of the
table.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: 'Thou shalt not steal'?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Ay, that he razed.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
Why, 'twas a commandment to
command
the captain and all the rest from
their functions: they
put forth to steal. There's
not a soldier of us all, that,
in the thanksgiving
before meat, do relish the petition
well
that prays for peace.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: I never heard any soldier dislike it.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
I believe thee; for I think thou
never wast
where grace was said.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: No? a dozen times at least.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p: What, in metre?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: In any proportion or in any language.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p: I think, or in any religion.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Ay, why not? Grace is grace, despite
of all controversy:
as for example, thou thyself
art a wicked
villain, despite of all grace.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
Well, there went but a pair of
shears between
us.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
I grant; as there may between the
lists and
the velvet. Thou art the list.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
And thou the velvet: thou art
good velvet;
thou'rt a three-piled piece, I
warrant thee: I had as lief
be a list of an
English kersey as be piled, as thou art
piled,
for a French velvet. Do I speak feelingly now?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
I think thou dost; and, indeed, with
most painful
feeling of thy speech: I will, out of
thine own confession,
learn to begin thy health;
but, whilst I live, forget
to drink after thee. 40

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
I think I have done myself
wrong, have I not?

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p:
Yes, that thou hast, whether
thou art tainted
or free.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Behold, behold, where Madam Mitigation
comes!
I have purchased as many diseases
under her roof
as come to--

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: To what, I pray?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Judge.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: To three thousand dolours a year.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p: Ay, and more.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: A French crown more.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
Thou art always figuring diseases
in me; but
thou art full of error; I am
sound.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Nay, not as one would say, healthy;
but so
sound as things that are hollow: thy
bones are hollow;
impiety has made a feast of
thee.
Enter MISTRESS OVERDONE.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
How now! which of your hips
has the most
profound sciatica?

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
Well, well; there's one yonder
arrested and
carried to prison was worth five
thousand of you all.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: Who's that, I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, that's Claudio, Signior
Claudio.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p: Claudio to prison? 'tis not so.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
Nay, but I know 'tis so: I saw
him arrested,
saw him carried away; and,
which is more, within these
three days his
head to be chopped off.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
But, after all this fooling, I would
not have it so.
Art thou sure of this?

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
I am too sure of it: and it is for
getting Madam
Julietta with child.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Believe me, this may be: he promised
to meet
me two hour? since, and he was
ever precise in
promise-keeping.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p:
Besides, you know, it draws
something near
to the speech we had to such
a purpose.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
But, most of all, agreeing with
the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Away! let's go learn the truth of it.
Exeunt Lucio and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
Thus, what with the war, what
with the sweat,
what with the gallows and
what with poverty, I am
custom-shrunk.
Enter POMPEY.
How now! what's the news with
you?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Yonder man is carried to prison.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p: Well; what has he done?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: A woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p: But what's his offence?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
What, is there a maid with child
by him?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
No, but there's a woman with maid
by him.
You have not heard of the proclamation,
have you?

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p: What proclamation, man?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
All houses in the suburbs of Vienna
in the suburbs be
pulled down?

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
And what shall become of those
in the city?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
They shall stand for seed: they had
gone down
too, but that a wise burgher put in
for them.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
But shall all our houses of resort
in the suburbs
be pulled down?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: To the ground, mistress.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
Why, here's a change indeed in the
commonwealth!
What shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Come; fear not you: good counsellors
lack
no clients: though you change your place,
you need
not change your trade; I'll be your
tapster still. Courage!
there will be pity taken
on you: you that have
worn your eyes almost
out in the service, you will be
considered.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
What's to do here, Thomas tapster?
let's
withdraw.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Here comes Signior Claudio, led by
the provost
to prison; and there's Madam
Juliet.
[Exeunt.
Enter PROVOST, CLAUDIO, JULIET, and
Officers.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world?
Bear me to prison, where I am committed.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: I do it not in evil disposition,
But from Lord Angelo by special charge.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thus can the demigod Authority
Make us pay down for our offence by weight
The words of heaven; on whom it will, it will;
On whom it will not, so; yet still 'tis just. Re-enter Lucio and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Why, how now, Claudio! whence comes this restraint?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty:
As surfeit is the father of much fast,
So every scope by the immoderate use
Turns to restraint. Our natures do pursue,
Like rats that ravin down their proper bane,
A thirsty evil; and when we drink we die.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
If I could speak so wisely under an
arrest, I
would send for certain of my creditors:
and yet, to say
the truth, I had as lief
have the foppery of freedom as
the morality of
imprisonment. What's thy offence,
Claudio?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: What but to speak of would offend again.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: What, is't murder?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Lechery?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Call it so.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p: Away sir! you must go.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l:
One word, good friend.
Lucio, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l:
A hundred,
if they'll do you any good.
Is lechery so look'd after?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract
I got possession of Julietta's bed:
You know the lady; she is fast my wife,
Save that we do the deunciation lack
Of outward order: this we came not to,
Only for propagation of a dower
Remaining in the coffer of her friends,
From whom we thought it meet to hide our love
Till time had made them for us. But it chances
The stealth of our most mutual entertainment
With character too gross is writ on Juliet.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: With child, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Unhappily, even so.
And the new deputy now for the duke--
Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness,
Or whether that the body public be
A horse whereon the governor doth ride,
Who, newly in the seat, that it may know
He can command, lets it straight feel the spur;
Whether the tyranny be in his place,
Or in his eminence that fills it up,
I stagger in:--but this new governor
Awakes me all the enrolled penalties
Which have, like unscour'd armour, hung by the wall
So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round
And none of them been worn; and, for a name,
Now puts the drowsy and neglected act
Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
I warrant it is: and thy head stands
so tickle on
thy shoulders that a milkmaid, if
she be in love, may
sigh it off. Send after
the duke and appeal to him.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I have done so, but he's not to be found.
I prithee, Lucio, do me this kind service:
This day my sister should the cloister enter
And there receive her approbation:
Acquaint her with the danger of my state;
Implore her, in my voice, that she make friends
To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him:
I have great hope in that; for in her youth
There is a prone and speechless dialect,
Such as move men; beside, she hath prosperous art
When she will play with reason and discourse,
And well she can persuade.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
I pray she may; as well for the encouragement
of the like, which else would stand
under grievous imposition,
as for the enjoying
of thy life, who I would be
sorry should be thus
foolishly lost at a game of tick-tack.
I'll to her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I thank you, good friend Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Within two hours.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l:
Come, officer, away!
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No, holy father; throw away that thought;
Believe not that the dribbling dart of love
Can pierce a complete bosom. Why I desire thee
To give me secret harbour, hath a purpose
More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends
Of burning youth.

sp.speaker: Fri. T.
sp.l: May your grace speak of it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My holy sir, none better knows than you
How I have ever loved the life removed
And held in idle price to haunt assemblies
Where youth, and cost, and witless bravery keeps.
I have deliver'd to Lord Angelo,
A man of stricture and firm abstinence,
My absolute power and place here in Vienna,
And he supposes me travell'd to Poland;
For so I have strew'd it in the common ear,
And so it is received. Now, pious sir,
You will demand of me why I do this?

sp.speaker: Fri. T.
sp.l: Gladly, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We have strict statutes and most biting laws,
The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds,
Which for this nineteen years we have let slip;
Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave,
That goes not out to prey. Now, as fond fathers,
Having bound up the threatening twigs of birch,
Only to stick it in their children's sight
For terror, not to use, in time the rod
Becomes more mock'd than fear'd; so our decrees,
Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead;
And liberty plucks justice by the nose;
The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart
Goes all decorum.

sp.speaker: Fri. T.
sp.l: It rested in your grace
To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased:
And it in you more dreadful would have seem'd
Than in Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I do fear, too dreadful:
Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope,
'Twould be my tyranny to strike and gall them
For what I bid them do: for we bid this be done,
When evil deeds have their permissive pass
And not the punishment. Therefore indeed, my father,
I have on Angelo imposed the office;
Who may, in the ambush of my name, strike home,
And yet my nature never in the fight
To do in slander. And to behold his sway,
I will, as 'twere a brother of your order,
Visit both prince and people: therefore, I prithee,
Supply me with the habit and instruct me
How I may formally in person bear me
Like a true friar. Moe reasons for this action
At our more leisure shall I render you;
Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise;
Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confesses
That his blood flows, or that his appetite
Is more to bread than stone: hence shall we see,

If power change purpose, what our seemers be.
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And have you nuns no farther privileges?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Are not these large enough?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes, truly: I speak not as desiring more;
But rather wishing a more strict restraint
Upon the sisterhood, the votarists of Saint Clare.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Ho! Peace be in this place!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Who's that which calls?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is a man's voice. Gentle Isabella,
Turn you the key, and know his business of him;
You may, I may not; you are yet unsworn.
When you have vow'd, you must not speak with men
But in the presence of the prioress:
Then, if you speak, you must not show your face,
Or, if you show your face, you must not speak.

He calls again; I pray you, answer him.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l:
Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls?
Enter Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Hail, virgin, if you be, as those cheek-roses
Proclaim you are no less! Can you so stead me
As bring me to the sight of Isabella,
A novice of this place and the fair sister
To her unhappy brother Claudio?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Why 'her unhappy brother'? let me ask,
The rather for I now must make you know
I am that Isabella and his sister.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you:
Not to be weary with you, he's in prison.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Woe me! for what?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: For that which, if myself might be his judge,
He should receive his punishment in thanks:
He hath got his friend with child.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Sir, make me not your story.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: It is true.
I would not--though 'tis my familiar sin
With maids to seem the lapwing and to jest,
Tongue far from heart--play with all virgins so:
I hold you as a thing ensky'd and sainted,
By your renouncement an immortal spirit,
And to be talk'd with in sincerity,
As with a saint.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Do not believe it. Fewness and truth, 'tis thus:
Your brother and his lover have embraced:
As those that feed grow full as blossoming time
That from the seedness the bare fallow brings
To teeming foison, even so her plenteous womb
Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Some one with child by him? My cousin Juliet?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Is she your cousin?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Adoptedly; as school-maids change their names
By vain though apt affection.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: She it is.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O, let him marry her.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: This is the point.
The duke is very strangely gone from hence;
Bore many gentlemen, myself being one,
In hand and hope of action: but we do learn
By those that know the very nerves of state,
His givings-out were of an infinite distance
From his true-meant design. Upon his place,
And with full line of his authority,
Governs Lord Angelo; a man whose blood
Is very snow-broth; one who never feels
The wanton stings and motions of the sense,
But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge
With profits of the mind, study and fast.
He--to give fear to use and liberty,
Which have for long run by the hideous law,
As mice by lions--hath pick'd out an act,
Under whose heavy sense your brother's life
Falls into forfeit: he arrests him on it;
And follows close the rigour of the statute,
To make him an example. All hope is gone,
Unless you have the grace by your fair prayer
To soften Angelo: and that's my pith of business
'Twixt you and your poor brother.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l:
Doth he so
seek his life?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Has censured him

Already;
and, as I hear, the provost hath

A warrant
for his execution.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l:
Alas! What poor
ability's in me
To do him good?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Assay the power you have.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My power? Alas, I doubt--

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Our doubts are traitors
And make us lose the good we oft might win
By fearing to attempt. Go to Lord Angelo,
And let him learn to know, when maidens sue,
Men give like gods; but when they weep and kneel,
All their petitions are as freely theirs
As they themselves would owe them.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I'll see what I can do.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: But speedily.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I will about it straight;
No longer staying but to give the mother
Notice of my affair. I humbly thank you:
Commend me to my brother: soon at night
I'll send him certain word of my success.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: I take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l:
Good sir, adieu.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter ANGELO, ESCALUS, and a Justice, Provost, Officers, and other Attendants, behind.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We must not make a scarecrow of the law,
Setting it up to fear the birds of prey,
And let it keep one shape, till custom make it
Their perch and not their terror.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: Ay, but yet
Let us be keen, and rather cut a little,
Than fall, and bruise to death. Alas, this gentleman,
Whom I would save, had a most noble father
Let but your honour know,
Whom I believe to be most strait in virtue,
That, in the working of your own affections,
Had time cohered with place or place with wishing,
Or that the resolute acting of your blood
Could have attain'd the effect of your own purpose,
Whether you had not sometime in your life
Err'd in this point which now you censure him,
And pull'd the law upon you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus,
Another thing to fall. I not deny,
The jury, passing on the prisoner's life,
May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two
Guiltier than him they try. What's open made to justice,
That justice seizes: what know the laws
That thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant,
The jewel that we find, we stoop and take't
Because we see it; but what we do not see
We tread upon, and never think of it.
You may not so extenuate his offence
For I have had such faults; but rather tell me,
When I, that censure him, do so offend,
Let mine own judgement pattern out my death,
And nothing come in partial. Sir, he must die.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: Be it as your wisdom will.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Where is the provost?

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: Here, if it like your honour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: See that Claudio
Be executed by nine to-morrow morning:
Bring him his confessor, let him be prepared;

For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.
[Exit Provost.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: Well, heaven forgive him! and forgive us all!
Some rise by sin, and some by virtue fall:
Some run from brakes of ice, and answer none:

And some condemned for a fault alone.
Enter ELBOW, and Officers with FROTH and POMPEY.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Come, bring them away: if these be
good people
in a commonweal that do nothing
but use their
abuses in common houses, I know
no law: bring them
away.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
How now, sir! What's your name?
and what's
the matter?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
If it please your honour, I am the
poor duke's
constable, and my name is Elbow:
I do lean upon justice,
sir, and do bring in
here before your good honour
two notorious
benefactors.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Benefactors? Well; what benefactors
are they?
are they not malefactors?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
If it please your honour, I know not
well what
they are: but precise villains they are,
that I am sure of;
and void of all profanation
in the world that good
Christians ought to
have.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
This comes off well; here's a wise
officer.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Go to: what quality are they of?
Elbow is
your name?
why dost though not
speak, Elbow?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: He cannot, sir; he's out at elbow.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
He, sir! a tapster, sir; parcel-bawd;
one that
serves a bad woman; whose house,
sir, was, as they say,
plucked down in the
suburbs; and now she professes a
hot-house,
which, I think, is a very ill house too.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
My wife, sir, whom I detest before
heaven and
your honour,--

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: How? thy wife?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Ay, sir; whom, I thank heaven, is an
honest
woman,--

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Dost thou detest her therefore?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
I say, sir, I will detest myself also, as
well as she,
that this house, if it be not a
bawd's house, it is pity of her
life, for it is a
naughty house.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: How dost thou know that, constable?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, by my wife; who, if she
had been a woman
cardinally given, might
have been accused in fornication,
adultery,
and all uncleanliness there.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: By the woman's means?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's
means: but as she spit
in his face, so she defied
him.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Sir, if it please your honour, this is
not so.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Prove it before these varlets here, thou
honourable
man; prove it.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Do you hear how he misplaces?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Sir, she came in great with child; and
longing,
saving your honour's reverence, for
stewed prunes; sir,
we had but two in the
house, which at that very distant
time stood, as
it were, in a fruit-dish, a dish of some threepence;
your honours have seen such dishes; they
are not
China dishes, but very good dishes,--

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Go to, go to: no matter for the dish,
sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you
are therein in
the right: but to the point. As
I say, this Mistress Elbow,
being, as I say,
with child, and being great-bellied, and
longing,
as I said, for prunes; and having but two
in
the dish, as I said, Master Froth here, this
very man, having
eaten the rest, as I said, and,
as I say, paying for them
very honestly; for,
as you know, Master Froth, I could not
give
you three-pence again.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Very well; you being then, if you be
remembered,
cracking the stones of the foresaid
prunes,--

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: Ay, so I did indeed.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Why, very well; I telling you then, if
you be
remembered, that such a one and such
a one were past
cure of the thing you wot of,
unless they kept very good
diet, as I told you,--

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: All this is true.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Why, very well, then,--

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Come, you are a tedious fool: to the
purpose.
What was done to Elbow's wife,
that he hath cause to
complain of? Come me
to what was done to her.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Sir, your honour cannot come to that
yet.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: No, sir, nor I mean it not.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Sir, but you shall come to it, by your
honour's
leave. And, I beseech you, look into
Master Froth here,
sir; a man of fourscore
pound a year; whose father
died at Hallowmas:
was't not a Hallowmas, Master
Froth?

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: All-hallond eve.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Why, very well; I hope here be
truth. He, sir,
sitting, as I say, in a lower
chair, sir; 'twas in the Bunch
of Grapes, where
indeed you have a delight to sit, have
you
not?

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p:
I have so; because it is an open
room and good
for winter.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Why, very well, then; I hope here
be truths.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: This will last out a night in Russia,
When nights are longest there: I'll take my leave,
And leave you to the hearing of the cause;
Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l:
I think no less. Good morrow to your lordship.
[Exit Angelo.
sp.p:
Now. sir come on: what was done to Elbow's
wife, once more?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Once, sir? there was nothing done to
her once.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
I beseech you, sir, ask him what this
man did to
my wife.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: I beseech your honour, ask me.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Well, sir; what did this gentleman
to her?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I beseech you, sir, look in this gentleman's
face.
Good Master Froth, look upon
his honour; 'tis for a good
purpose. Doth
your honour mark his face?

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Ay, sir, very well.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech ycu, mark it well.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Well, I do so,

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Doth your honour see any harm in
his face?

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Why, no.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I'll be supposed upon a book, his face
is the worst
thing about him. Good, then; if
his face be the worst
thing about him, how
could Master Froth do the constable's
wife any
harm? I would know that of
your honour.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
He's in the right. Constable, what
say you to it?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
First, an it like you, the house is a respected


house; next, this is a respected fellow;

and his mistress is 
a respected woman.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
By this hand, sir, his wife is a more
respected person
than any of us all.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked
varlet! the
time is yet to come that she was
ever respected with
man, woman, or child.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Sir, she was respected with him before
he married
with her.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Which is the wiser here? Justice or
Iniquity? Is
this true?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
O thou caitiff! O thou varlet! O thou
wicked
Hannibal! I respected with her before
I was married
to her! If ever I was respected
with her, or she with me,
let not your worship
think me the poor duke's officer.
Prove this.
thou wicked Hannibal, or I'll have
mine
action of battery on thee.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
If he took you a box o' the ear, you
might have
your action of slander too.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry, I thank your good worship for
it. What
is't your worship's pleasure I shall
do with this wicked
caitiff?

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Truly, officer, because he hath some
offences in
him that thou wouldst discover if
thou couldst let him
continue in his courses
till thou knowest what they are.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry, I thank your worship for it.
Thou seest,
thou wicked varlet, now, what's
come upon thee: thou
art to continue now,
thou varlet; thou art to continue.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Where were you born, friend?

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: Here in Vienna, sir.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Are you of fourscore pounds a year?

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: Yes, an't please you, sir.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: So. What trade are you of, sir?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: A tapster; a poor widow's tapster.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Your mistress' name?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Mistress Overdone.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Hath she had any more than one
husband?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Nine, sir; Overdone by the last.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Nine! Come hither to me. Master
Master
Froth, I would not have you
acquainted with tapsters:
they will draw you,
Master Froth, and you will hang them.
Get
you gone, and let me hear no more of you.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p:
I thank your worship. For mine
own part, I
never come into any room in a
tap-house, but I am
drawn in.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Well, no more of it, Master Froth:
farewell. [Exit Froth.

Come you hither to me,
Master tapster. What's your name,
Master
tapster?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Pompey.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Bum, sir.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Troth, and your bum is the greatest
thing about
you; so that in the beastliest sense
you are Pompey the
Great. Pompey, you are
partly a bawd, Pompey, howsoever
you colour
it in being a tapster, are you not? Come,
tell
me true: it shall, be the better for you.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Truly, sir, I am a poor fellow that
would live.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
How would you live, Pompey? by
being a bawd?
What do you think of the
trade, Pompey? is it a lawful
trade?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: If the law would allow it, sir.

sp.speaker: Escal.
Pom.
sp.p:
Does your worship mean to geld and
splay all
the youth of the city?

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: No, Pompey.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they
will to't
then. If your worship will take order
for the drabs and
the knaves, you need not to
fear the bawds.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
There are pretty orders beginning, I
can tell you:
it is but heading and hanging.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
If you head and hang all that offend
that way
but for ten year together, you'll be
glad to give out a
commission for more heads:
if this law hold in Vienna
ten year, I'll rent
the fairest house in it after three-pence
a bay:
if you live to see this come to pass, say Pompey
told you so.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Thank you, good Pompey; and, in
requital of
your prophecy, hark you, I advise
you, let me not find
you before me again upon
any complaint whatsoever;
no, not for dwelling
where you do: if I do, Pompey, I
shall beat
you to your tent, and prove a shrewd Caesar
to you; in plain dealing, Pompey, I shall
have you whipt:
so, for this time, Pompey,
fare you well.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I thank your worship for your good
counsel: [Aside]
but I shall follow it as the
flesh and fortune shall better
determine.
sp.l: Whip me? No, no; let carman whip his jade:

The valiant heart's not whipt out of his trade.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Come hither to me, Master Elbow;

come hither, 
Master constable.   How long

have you been in this place 
of constable?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: Seven year and a half, sir.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
I thought, by your readiness in the
office, you had
continued in it some time. You
say, seven years
together?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: And a half, sir.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Alas, it hath been great pains to
you. They do
you wrong to put you so oft
upon't: are there not men
in your ward sufficient
to serve it?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters:
as they
are chosen, they are glad to
choose me for them; I do it
for some piece of
money, and go through with all.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
Look you bring me in the names of
some six
or seven, the most sufficient of your
parish.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: To your worship's house, sir?

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
To my house. Fare you well.
[Exit Elbow.
What's o'clock,
think you?

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: Eleven, sir.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: I pray you home to dinner with me.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.p: I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: It grieves me for the death of Claudio;
But there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: Lord Angelo is severe.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.l: It is but needful:
Mercy is not itself, that oft looks so;
Pardon is still the nurse of second woe:
But yet,--poor Claudio! There is no remedy.

Come, sir.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He's hearing of a cause; he will come straight:
I'll tell him of you.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: Pray you, do. [Exit Servant.] I'll know
His pleasure; may be he will relent. Alas,
He hath but as offended in a dream!
All sects, all ages smack of this vice; and he

To die for't!
Enter ANGELO.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now, what's the matter, provost?

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Did not I tell thee yea? hadst thou not order?
Why dost thou ask again?

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: Lest I might be too rash:
Under your good correction. I have seen,
When, after execution, judgement hath
Repented o'er his doom.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Go to; let that be mine:
Do you your office. or give up your place,
And you shall well be spared.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: I crave your honour's pardon.
What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet?
She's very near her hour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Dispose of her

To some more fitter place, and that with speed.
Re-enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Here is the sister of the man condemn'd
Desires access to you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hath he a sister?

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: Ay, my good lord; a very virtuous maid,
And to be shortly of a sisterhood,
If not already.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l:
Well, let her be admitted.
[Exit Servant.
See you the fornicatress be removed:
Let her have needful, but not lavish, means;

There shall be order for't.
Enter ISABELLA and LUCIO.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: God save your honour!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Stay a little while. To Isab.
You're welcome: what's your will?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I am a woeful suitor to your honour,
Please but your honour hear me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well; what's your suit?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: There is a vice that most I do abhor,
And most desire should meet the blow of justice;
For which I would not plead, but that I must;
For which I must not plead, but that I am
At war 'twixt will and will not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well; the matter?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I have a brother is condemn'd to die:
I do beseech you, let it be his fault,
And not my brother.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: Heaven give thee moving graces!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Condemn the fault, and not the actor of it?
Why, every fault's condemn'd ere it be done:
Mine were the very cipher of a function,
To fine the faults whose fine stands in record,
And let go by the actor.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O just but severe law!
I had a brother, then. Heaven keep your honour!

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Give't not o'er so: to him again, entreat him;
Kneel down before him, hang upon his gown:
You are too cold; if you should need a pin,
You could not with more tame a tongue desire it:
To him, I say!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Must he needs die?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Maiden, no remedy.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes; I do think that you might pardon him,
And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will not do't.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: But can you, if you would?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: But might you do't, and do the world no wrong,
If so your heart were touch'd with that remorse
As mine is to him?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: He's sentenced; 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: You are too cold.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Too late? why, no; I, that do speak a word,
May call it back again. Well, believe this,
No ceremony that to great ones 'longs,
Not the king's crown, nor the deputed sword,
The marshal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe,
Become them with one half so good a grace
As mercy does.
If he had been as you and you as he,
You would have slipt like him; but he, like you,
Would not have been so stern.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray you, be gone.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I would to heaven I had your potency,
And you were Isabel! should it then be thus?
No; I would tell what 'twere to be a judge,
And what a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Ay, touch him; there's the vein.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Your brother is a forfeit of the law,
And you but waste your words.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Alas, alas!
Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once;
And He that might the vantage best have took
Found out the remedy. How would you be,
If He, which is the top of judgement, should
But judge you as you are? O, think on that;
And mercy then will breathe within your lips
Like man new made.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Be you content, fair maid;
It is the law, not I condemn your brother:
Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son,
It should be thus with him: he must die tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: To-morrow! O, that's sudden! Spare him, spare him!
He's not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens
We kill the fowl of season: shall we serve heaven
With less respect than we do minister
To our gross selves? Good, good my lord, bethink you;
Who is it that hath died for this offence?
There's many have committed it.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Ay, well said.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The law hath not been dead, though it hath slept:
Those many had not dared to do that evil,
If the first that did the edict infringe
Had answer'd for his deed: now 'tis awake,
Takes note of what is done; and, like a prophet,
Looks in a glass, that shows what future evils,
Either new, or by remissness new-conceived,
And so in progress to be hatch'd and born,
Are now to have no successive degrees,
But, ere they live, to end.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yet show some pity.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I show it most of all when I show justice;
For then I pity those I do not know,
Which a dismiss'd offence would after gall;
And do him right that, answering one foul wrong,
Lives not to act another. Be satisfied;
Your brother dies to-morrow; be content.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: So you must be the first that gives this sentence,
And he, that suffers. O, it is excellent
To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous
To use it like a giant.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: That's well said.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Could great men thunder
As Jove himself does, Jove would ne'er be quiet,
For every pelting, petty officer
Would use his heaven for thunder;
Nothing but thunder! Merciful Heaven,
Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt
Split'st the unwedgeable and gnarled oak
Than the soft myrtle: but man, proud man,
Drest in a little brief authority,
Most ignorant of what he's most assured,
His glassy essence, like an angry ape,
Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven
As make the angels weep; who, with our spleens,
Would all themselves laugh mortal.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: O, to him, to him, wench! he will relent;
He's coming; I perceive't.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: Pray heaven she win him!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: We cannot weigh our brother with ourself:
Great men may jest with saints; 'tis wit in them,
But in the less foul profanation.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Thou'rt i' the right, girl; more o' that.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: That in the captain's but a choleric word,
Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Art avised o' that? more on't.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why do you put these sayings upon me?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Because authority, though it err like others,
Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself,
That skins the vice o' the top. Go to your bosom;
Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know
That's like my brother's fault: if it confess
A natural guiltiness such as is his,
Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue
Against my brother's life.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: She speaks, and 'tis
Such sense, that my sense breeds with it. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Gentle my lord, turn back.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will bethink me: come again tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Hark how I'll bribe you: good my lord, turn back.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How! bribe me?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ay, with such gifts that heaven shall share with you.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: You had marr'd all else.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Not with fond shekels of the tested gold,
Or stones whose rates are either rich or poor
As fancy values them; but with true prayers
That shall be up at heaven and enter there
Ere sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls,
From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate
To nothing temporal.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well; come to me to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Go to; 'tis well; away!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Heaven keep your honour safe!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Amen:
For I am that way going to temptation,
Where prayers cross.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: At what hour to-morrow
Shall I attend your worship?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: At any time 'fore noon.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l:
'Save your honour!
[Exeunt Isabella, Luclo, and Provost.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: From thee, even from thy virtue!
What's this, what's this? Is this her fault or mine,
The tempter or the tempted, who sins most?
Ha!
Not she; nor doth she tempt: but it is I
That, lying by the violet in the sun,
Do as the carrion does, not as the flower,
Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it be
That modesty may more betray our sense
Than woman's lightness? Having waste ground enough,
Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary
And pitch our evils there? O, fie, fie, fie!
What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo?
Dost thou desire her foully for those things
That make her good? O, let her brother live:
Thieves for their robbery have authority
When judges steal themselves. What, do I love her,
That I desire to hear her speak again,
And feast upon her eyes? What is't I dream on?
O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint,
With saints dost bait thy hook! Most dangerous
Is that temptation that doth goad us on
To sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet,
With all her double vigour, art and nature,
Once stir my temper; but this virtuous maid
Subdues me quite. Ever till now,

When men were fond, I smiled and wonder'd how.
[Exit.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage: Enter, severally, DUKE disguised as a friar, and PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hail to you, provost! so I think you are.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: I am the provost. What's your will, good friar?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bound by my charity and my blest order,
I come to visit the afflicted spirits
Here in the prison. Do me the common right
To let me see them and to make me know
The nature of their crimes, that I may minister
To them accordingly.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l:
I would do more than that, if more were needed.
Enter JULIET.
Look here comes one: a gentlewoman of mine,
Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth,
Hath blister'd her report: she is with child;
And he that got it, sentenced; a young man
More fit to do another such office
Than die tor this.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: When must he die?

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: As I do think, to-morrow,
I have provided for you: stay awhile, [To Juliet.]
And you shall be conducted.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do; and bear the shame most patiently.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience,
And try your penitence, if it be sound,
Or hollowly put on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll gladly learn.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Love you the man that wrong'd you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, as I love the woman that wrong'd him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: So then it seems your most offenceful act
Was mutually committed?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mutually.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do confess it, and repent it, father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis meet so, daughter: but lest you do repent,
As that the sin hath brought you to this shame,
Which sorrow is always toward ourselves, not heaven,
Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it,
But as we stand in fear,--

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do repent me, as it is an evil,
And take the shame with joy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There rest.
Your partner, as I hear, must die to-morrow,
And I am going with instruction to him.
Grace go with you, Benedicite! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Must die to-morrow! O injurious love,
That respites me a life, whose very comfort
Is still a dying horror!

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: 'Tis pity of him. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: When I would pray and think, I think and pray
To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words;
Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue,
Anchors on Isabel: Heaven in my mouth,
As if I did but only chew his name;
And in my heart the strong and swelling evil
Of my conception. The state, whereon I studied,
Is like a good thing, being often read,
Grown fear'd and tedious; yea, my gravity,
Wherein--let no man hear me--I take pride,
Could I with boot change for an idle plume,
Which the air beats for vain. O place, O form,
How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit,
Wrench awe from fools and tie the wiser souls
To thy false seeming! Blood, thou art blood:
Let's write good angel on the devil's horn;
'Tis not the devil's crest. Enter a SERVANT.
Now now! who's there?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Teach her the way. [Exit Serv.
O heavens!
Why does my blood thus muster to my heart,
Making both it unable for itself,
And dispossessing all my other parts
Of necessary fitness?
So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons;
Come all to help him, and so stop the air
By which he should revive: and even so
The general, subject to a well-wish'd king,
Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondness
Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love
Must needs appear offence. Enter ISABELLA.
How now, fair maid?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I am come to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: That you might know it, would much better please me
Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Even so. Heaven keep your honour!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yet may he live awhile; and, it may be,
As long as you or I: yet he must die.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Under your sentence?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yea.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: When, I beseech you? that in his reprieve,
Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted
That his soul sicken not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Ha! fie, these filthy vices! It were as good
To pardon him that hath from nature stolen
A man already made, as to remit
Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image
In stamps that are forbid: 'tis all as easy
Falsely to take away a life true made
As to put metal in restrained means
To make a false one.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Say you so? then I shall pose you quickly.
Which had you rather, that the most just law
Now took your brother's life; or, to redeem him,
Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness
As she that he hath stain'd?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Sir, believe this,
I had rather give my body than my soul.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I talk not of your soul: our compell'd sins
Stand more for number than for accompt.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: How say you?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay, I'll not warrant that; for I can speak
Against the thing I say. Answer to this:
I, now the voice of the recorded law,
Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life:
Might there not be a charity in sin
To save this brother's life?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Please you to do't.
I'll take it as a peril to my soul,
It is no sin at all, but charity.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul,
Were equal poise of sin and charity.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: That I do beg his life if it be sin,
Heaven let me bear it! you granting of my suit,
If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer
To have it added to the faults of mine,
And nothing of your answer.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay, but hear me.
Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant,
Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good,
But graciously to know I am no better.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright
When it doth tax itself; as these black masks
Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder
Than beauty could, display'd. But mark me;
To be received plain, I'll speak more gross:
Your brother is to die.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And his offence is so, as it appears,
Accountant to the law upon that pain.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Admit no other way to save his life,--
As I subscribe not that, nor any other,
But in the loss of question,--that you, his sister,
Finding yourself desired of such a person,
Whose credit with the judge, or own great place,
Could fetch your brother from the manacles
Of the all-building law; and that there were
No earthly mean to save him, but that either
You must lay down the treasures of your body
To this supposed, or else to let him suffer,
What would you do?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: As much for my poor brother as myself:
That is, were I under the terms of death,
The impression of keen whips I'ld wear as rubies,
And strip myself to death, as to a bed
That longing have been sick for, ere I'ld
My body up to shame.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Then must your brother die.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And 'twere the cheaper way:
Better it were a brother died at once,
Than that a sister, by redeeming him,
Should die for ever.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Were not you then as cruel as the sentence
That you have slander'd so?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ignomy in ransom and free pardon
Are of two houses: lawful mercy
Is nothing kin to foul redemption.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You seem'd of late to make the law a tyrant;
And rather proved the sliding of your brother
A merriment than a vice.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O, pardon me, my lord; it oft falls out,

To have what we would have,
we speak not what we mean:
I something do excuse the thing I hate,
For his advantage that I dearly love,

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We are all frail.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Else let my brother die,
If not a feodary, but only he
Owe and succeed thy weakness.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay, women are frail too.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves;
Which are as easy broke as they make forms.
Women! Help Heaven! men their creation mar
In profiting by them. Nay, call us ten times frail;
For we are soft as our complexions are,
And credulous to false prints.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I think it well:
And from this testimony of your own sex,--
Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger
Than faults may shake our frames,--let me be bold:
I do arrest your words. Be that you are,
That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none;
If you be one, as you are well express'd
By all external warrants, show it now,
By putting on the destined livery.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord,
Let me entreat you speak the former language.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Plainly conceive, I love you.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My brother did love Juliet,
And you tell me that he shall die for it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I know your virtue hath a license in't,
Which seems a little fouler than it is,
To pluck on others.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Believe me, on mine honour,
My words express my purpose.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ha! little honour to be much believed,
And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming!
I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't:
Sign me a present pardon for my brother,
Or with an outstretch'd throat I'll tell the world aloud
What man thou art.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Who will believe thee, Isabel?
My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life,
My vouch against you, and my place i' the state,
Will so your accusation overweigh,
That you shall stifle in your own report
And smell of calumny. I have begun,
And now I give my sensual race the rein:
Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite;
Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes,
That banish what they sue for; redeem thy brother
By yielding up thy body to my will;
Or else he must not only die the death,
But thy unkindness shall his death draw out
To lingering sufferance. Answer me to-morrow,
Or, by the affection that now guides me most,
I'll prove a tyrant to him. As for you,

Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: To whom should I complain? Did I tell this,
Who would believe me? O perilous mouths,
That bear in them one and the self-same tongue,
Either of condemnation or approof;
Bidding the law make court'sy to their will;
Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite,
To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother:
Though he hath fall'n by prompture of the blood,
Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour,
That, had he twenty heads to tender down
On twenty bloody blocks, he'ld yield them up,
Before his sister should her body stoop
To such abhorr'd pollution.
Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die:
More than our brother is our chastity.
I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request,

And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest
[Exit

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage: Enter DUKE disguised as before, CLAUDIO, and PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: The miserable have no other medicine
But only hope:

I've hope to live, and am prepared to
die,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be absolute for death; either death or life
Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life:
If I do lose thee, I do lose a thing
That none but fools would keep: a breath thou art,
Servile to all the skyey influences,
That dost this habitation, where thou keep'st,
Hourly afflict: merely, thou art death's fool;
For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shun
And yet runn'st toward him still. Thou art not noble;
For all the accommodations that thou bear'st
Are nursed by baseness. Thou'rt by no means valiant;
For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork
Of a poor worm. Thy best of rest is sleep,
And that thou oft provokes; yet grossly fear'st
Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thyself;
For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains
That issue out of dust. Happy thou art not;
For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get,
And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou art not certain;
For thy complexion shifts to strange effects,
After the moon. If thou art rich, thou'rt poor;
For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows,
Thou bear'st thy heavy riches but a journey,
And death unloads thee. Friend hast thou none;
For thine own bowels, which do call thee sire,
The mere effusion of thy proper loins,
Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum,
For ending thee no sooner. Thou hast nor youth nor age,
But, as it were, an after-dinner's sleep,
Dreaming on both; for ail thy blessed youth
Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms
Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich,
Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty,
To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in this
That bears the name of life? Yet in this life
Lie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear,
That makes these odds all even.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I humbly thank you.
To sue to live, I find I seek to die;
And seeking death, find life: let it come on.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l:
What, ho! Peace here; grace and good
company!

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l:
Who's there? come in: the wish deserves a
welcome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l:
Most holy sir, I thank you.
Enter ISABELLA.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: My business is a word or two with Claudio.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l:
And very welcome. Look, signior, here's your
sister.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Provost, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.l: As many as you please.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring me to hear them speak, where

I may be
concealed.
[Exeunt Duke and Provost.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Now, sister, what's the comfort?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Why,
As all comforts are; most good, most good indeed.
Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven,
Intends you for his swift ambassador,
Where you shall be an everlasting leiger:
Therefore your best appointment make with speed;
To-morrow you set on.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: None, but such remedy as, to save a head,
To cleave a heart in twain.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: But is there any?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes, brother, you may live:
There is a devilish mercy in the judge,
If you'll implore it, that will free your life,
But fetter you till death.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Perpetual durance?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Ay, just; perpetual durance, a restraint,
Though all the world's vastidity you had,
To a determined scope.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: But in what nature?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: In such a one as, you consenting to't,
Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear,
And leave you naked.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Let me know the point.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O, I do fear thee, Claudio; and I quake,
Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain,
And six or seven winters more respect
Than a perpetual honour. Darest thou die?
The sense of death is most in apprehension;
And the poor beetle, that we tread upon,
In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great
As when a giant dies.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Why give you me this shame?
Think you I can a resolution fetch
From flowery tenderness? If I must die,
I will encounter darkness as a bride,
And hug it in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: There spake my brother; there my father's grave
Did utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die:
Thou art too noble to conserve a life
In base appliances. This outward-sainted deputy,
Whose settled visage and deliberate word
Nips youth i' the head and follies doth emmew
As falcon doth the fowl, is yet a devil;
His filth within being cast, he would appear
A pond as deep as hell.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: The prenzie Angelo!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell,
The damned'st body to invest and cover
In prenzie guards! Dost thou think, Claudio?
If I would yield him my virginity,
Thou mightst be freed.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O heavens! it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes, he would give't thee, from this rank offence,
So to offend him still. This night's the time
That I should do what I abhor to name,
Or else thou diest to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thou shalt not do't

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O, were it but my life,
I'ld throw it down for your deliverance
As frankly as a pin.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Thanks, dear Isabel.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Yes. Has he affections in him,
That thus can make him bite the law by the nose,
When he would force it? Sure, it is no sin;
Or of the deadly seven it is the least.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Which is the least?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: If it were damnable, he being so wise,
Why would he for the momentary trick
Be perdurably fined? O Isabel!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: What says my brother?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Death is a fearful thing.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: And shamed life a hateful.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Ay, but to die, and go we know not where;
To lie in cold obstruction and to rot;
This sensible warm motion to become
A kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit
To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside
In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice;
To be imprison'd in the viewless winds,
And blown with restless violence round about
The pendent world; or to be worse than worst
Of those that lawless and incertain thought
Imagine howling: 'tis too horrible!
The weariest and most loathed worldly life
That age, ache, penury and imprisonment
Can lay on nature is a paradise
To what we fear of death.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Alas, alas!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Sweet sister, let me live:
What sin you do to save a brother's life,
Nature dispenses with the deed so far
That it becomes a virtue.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O you beast!
O faithless coward! O dishonest wretchl
Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice?
Is't not a kind of incest, to take life
From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?
Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair!
For such a warped slip of wilderness
Ne'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance!
Die, perish! Might but my bending down
Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed:
I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death,
No word to save thee.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Nay, hear me, Isabel.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: O, fie, fie, fie!
Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade.
Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd:
'Tis best that thou diest quickly.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l:
O hear me, Isabella!
Re-enter DUKE.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Might you dispense with your leisure,
I would
by and by have some speech
with you: the satisfaction I
would require is
likewise your own benefit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I have no superfluous leisure; my stay
must be
stolen out of other affairs; but I will
attend you awhile.
[Walks apart.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Son, I have overheard what hath
passed between
you and your sister. Angelo
had never the purpose to corrupt
her; only he
hath made an assay of her virtue to
practise his
judgement with the disposition of natures:
she,
having the truth of honour in her, hath made
him
that gracious denial which he is most glad
to receive. I
am confessor to Angelo, and I
know this to be true; therefore
prepare yourself
to death: do not satisfy your resolution
with hopes that are fallible: to-morrow you
must die; go to your knees and make ready.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Let me ask my sister pardon. I am
so out of love
with life that I will sue to be
rid of it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Hold you there: farewell.
[Exit Claudio.
Provost, a word
with you!
Re-enter PROVOST.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p: What's your will, father?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That now you are come, you will be
gone. Leave
me awhile with the maid: my
mind promises with my
habit no loss shall
touch her by my company.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p:
In good time.
Exit Provost. sabella comes forward.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
The hand that hath made you fair
hath made
you good: the goodness that is cheap
in beauty makes
beauty brief in goodness; but
grace, being the soul of
your complexion, shall
keep the body of it ever fair.
The assault that
Angelo hath made to you, fortune hath
conveyed
to my understanding; and, but that
frailty hath
examples for his falling, I should
wonder at Angelo. How
will you do to content
this substitute, and to save your
brother?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I am now going to resolve him; I had
rather
my brother die by the law than my son
should be unlawfully
born. But, O, how much
is the good duke
deceived in Angelo! If ever
he return and I can speak
to him, I will open
my lips in vain, or discover his
government.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That shall not be much amiss: yet,
as the matter
now stands, he will avoid your
accusation; he made
trial of you only. Therefore
fasten your ear on my
advisings: to the
love I have in doing good a remedy
presents
itself. I do make myself believe that you
may
most uprighteously do a poor wronged lady a
merited
benefit; redeem your brother from the
angry law;
do no stain to your own gracious
person; and much
please the absent duke, if
peradventure he shall ever return
to have hearing
of this business.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Let me hear you speak farther. I
have spirit to
do any thing that appears not
foul in the truth of my
spirit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Virtue is bold, and goodness never
fearful.
Have you not heard speak of Mariana,
the sister of Frederick
the great soldier
who miscarried at sea?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I have heard of the lady, and good
words went
with her name.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
She should this Angelo have married;
was affianced
to her by oath, and the nuptial
appointed: between
which time of the contract
and limit of the solemnity,
her brother Frederick
was wrecked at sea, having in that
perished
vessel the dowry of his sister. But mark
how
heavily this befell to the poor gentlewoman:
there she
lost a noble and renowned
brother, in his love toward
her ever most kind
and natural; with him, the portion and
sinew of
her fortune, her marriage-dowry; with
both, her
combinate husband, this well-seeming
Angelo.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Can this be so? did Angelo so leave
her?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Left her in her tears, and dried not
one of them
with his comfort; swallowed his
vows whole, pretending
in her discoveries of
dishonour: in few, bestowed
her on her own
lamentation, which she yet wears for
his sake;
and he, a marble to her tears, is washed with
them, but relents not.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
What a merit were it in death to take
this poor
maid from the world! What corruption
in this life, that
it will let this man live!
But how out of this can she
avail?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It is a rupture that you may easily
heal: and the
cure of it not only saves your
brother, but keeps you
from dishonour in doing
it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Show me how, good father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
This forenamed maid hath yet in her
the continuance
of her first affection: his unjust
unkindness,
that in all reason should have
quenched her love, hath,
like an impediment
in the current, made it more violent
and unruly.
Go you to Angelo; answer his requiring
with a plausible obedience; agree with his demands
to the point; only refer yourself to this
advantage,
first, that your stay with him may
not be long; that the
time may have all shadow
and silence in it; and the place
answer to convenience.
This being granted in course,--
and
now follows all,--we shall advise this wronged
maid to stead up your appointment, go in your
place;
if the encounter acknowledge itself
hereafter, it may
compel him to her recompense:
and here, by this, is
your brother saved,
your honour untainted, the poor
Mariana advantaged,
and the corrupt deputy scaled.
The
maid will I frame and make fit for this attempt.
If
you think well to carry this as you
may, the doubleness
of the benefit defends the
deceit from reproof. What
think you of it?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
The image of it gives me content
already; and I
trust it will grow to a most
prosperous perfection.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It lies much in your holding up. Haste
you speedily
to Angelo: if for this night he
entreat you to his bed,
give him promise of satisfaction.
I will presently to Saint
Luke's: there,
at the moated grange, resides this dejected
Mariana. At that place call upon me; and dispatch
with Angelo, that it may be quickly.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I thank you for this comfort. Fare
you well, good
father.
Exeunt severally.

div2.head: SCENE II

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but
that you
will needs buy and sell men and
women like beasts, we
shall have all the world
drink brown and white bastard.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O heavens! what stuff is here?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
'Twas never merry world since, of two
usuries,
the merriest was put down, and the
worser allowed by
order of law a furred gown
to keep him warm; and
furred with fox and
lambskins too, to signify, that craft,
being
richer than innocency, stands for the facing.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Come your way, sir. 'Bless you, good
father
friar.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
And you, good brother father. What
offence
hath this man made you, sir?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, he hath offended the law:
and, sir,
we take him to be a thief too, sir; for
we have found
upon him, sir, a strange picklock,
which we have sent
to the deputy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Fie, sirrah! a bawd, a wicked bawd!
The evil that thou causest to be done,
That is thy means to live. Do thou but think
What 'tis to cram a maw or clothe a back
From such a filthy vice: say to thyself,
From their abominable and beastly touches
I drink, I eat, array myself, and live.
Canst thou believe thy living is a life,
So stinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

sp.speaker: Pom.
Duke.
sp.l: Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin,
Thou wilt prove his. Take him to prison, officer:
Correction and instruction must both work
Ere this rude beast will profit.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
He must before the deputy, sir; he
has given
him warning: the deputy cannot
abide a whoremaster:
if he be a whoremonger,
and comes before him,
he were as good
go a mile on his errand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That we were all, as some would seem to be,
From our fault as faults from seeming, free!

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: His neck will come to your waist,--a cord, sir.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I spy comfort; I cry bail. Here's a
gentleman
and a friend of mine.
Enter Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
How now, noble Pompey! What,
at the wheels
of Caesar? art thou led in triumph?
What, is there none
of Pygmalion's
images, newly made woman, to be had
now,
for putting the hand in the pocket and extracting
it
clutched? What reply, ha? What
sayest thou to this
tune, matter and method?
Is't not drowned i' the last
rain, ha? What
sayest thou, Trot? Is the world as it was,
man? Which is the way? Is it sad, and few
words?
or how? The trick of it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Still thus, and thus; still worse!

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
How doth my dear morsel, thy mis-
tress? Procures
she still, ha?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her
beef, and
she is herself in the tub.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Why, 'tis good; it is the right of it;

it must be 
so: ever your fresh whore and your

powdered bawd: an 
unshunned consequence;

it must be so. Art going to prison, 
Pompey?

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: Yes, faith, sir.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey: Farewell:
go say
I sent thee thither. For debt,
Pompey, or how?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: For being a bawd, for being a bawd.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Well, then, imprison him: if imprisonment
be
the due of a bawd, why, 'tis
his right: bawd is he doubtless,
and of antiquity
too; bawd-born. Farewell, good
Pompey.
Commend me to the prison, Pompey:
you will
turn good husband now, Pompey;
you will keep the
house.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p:
I hope, sir, your good worship will
be my bail.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it
is not the wear.
I will pray, Pompey, to
increase your bondage: if you
take it not patiently,
why, your mettle is the more.
Adieu,
trusty Pompey,
'Bless you, friar.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And you.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: Come your ways, sir; come.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.p: You will not bail me, then, sir?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Then, Pompey, nor now. What
news abroad, friar?
what news?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: Come your ways, sir; come.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Go to kennel, Pompey; go.
[Exeunt Elbow, Pompey and Officers.]
What news, friar, of the duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I know none. Can you tell me of any?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Some say he is with the Emperor of
Russia; other
some, he is in Rome: but where
is he, think you?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I know not where; but wheresoever,
I wish
him well.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
It was a mad fantastical trick of him
to steal
from the state, and usurp the beggary he
was never
born to. Lord Angelo dukes it well
in his absence; he
puts transgression to't.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: He does well in't.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
A little more lenity to lechery would
do no
harm in him: something too crabbed
that way, friar.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It is too general a vice, and severity
must cure it.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a
great kindred;
it is well allied: but it is impossible
to extirp it quite,
friar, till eating and
drinking be put down. They say
this Angelo
was not made by man and woman after
this
downright way of creation: is it true, think
you?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How should he be made, then?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Some report a sea-maid spawned
him; some,
that he was begot between two
stock-fishes. But it
is certain that when he
makes water his urine is congealed
ice; that I
know to be true: and he is a motion
generative;
that's infallible.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
You are pleasant, sir, and speak
apace.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Why, what a ruthless thing is this in
him, for
the rebellion of a codpiece to take away
the life of a
man! Would the duke that is absent
have done this?
Ere he would have hanged
a man for the getting a hundred
bastards, he
would have paid for the nursing a
thousand:
he had some feeling of the sport; he knew
the
service, and that instructed him to mercy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I never heard the absent duke much
detected
for women; he was not inclined that
way.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: O, sir, you are deceived.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Who, not the duke? yes, your beggar
of fifty;
and his use was to put a ducat in her
clack-dish: the
duke had crotchets in him. He
would be drunk too;
that let me inform
you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You do him wrong, surely.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Sir, I was an inward of his. A shy
fellow was
the duke: and I believe I know
the cause of his
withdrawing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What, I prithee, might be the cause?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
No, pardon; 'tis a secret must be
locked within
the teeth and the lips: but this I
can let you understand,
the greater file of the
subject held the duke to be
wise.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Wise! why, no question but he was.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing
fellow.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Either this is envy in you, folly, or
mistaking:
the very stream of his life and the
business he
hath helmed must upon a warranted
need give him
a better proclamation.
Let him be but testimonied in
his own bringings-forth,
and he shall appear to the
envious
a scholar, a statesman and a soldier. Therefore
you speak unskilfully; or if your knowledge
be
more it is much darkened in your malice.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Sir, I know him, and I love him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Love talks with better knowledge,
and knowledge with dearer love.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: Come, sir, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I can hardly believe that, since you
know not
what you speak. But, if ever the
duke return, as our
prayers are he may, let me
desire you to make your answer
before him.
If it be honest you have spoke, you
have courage
to maintain it: I am bound to call upon
you; and, I pray you, your name?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Sir, my name is Lucio; well known
to the duke.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
He shall know you better, sir, if I
may live to
report you.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p: I fear you not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
O, you hope the duke will return no
more;
or you imagine me too unhurtful an
opposite. But indeed
I can do you little harm;
you'll forswear this
again.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
I'll be hanged first: thou art deceived
in me,
friar. But no more of this. Canst thou
tell if Claudio
die to-morrow or no?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why should he die, sir?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.p:
Why? For filling a bottle with a
tun-dish.
I would the duke we talk of were
returned again: this
ungenitured agent will
unpeople the province with
continency; sparrows
must not build in his house-eaves,
because
they are lecherous. The duke yet would
have
dark deeds darkly answered; he would never
bring them to light: would he were returned!
Marry,
this Claudio is condemned for untrussing.
Farewell, good
friar: I prithee, pray
for me. The duke, I say to thee
again, would
eat mutton on Fridays. He's not past
it yet,
and I say to thee, he would mouth with a beggar,
though she smelt brown bread and garlic:
say
that I said so. Farewell.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No might nor greatness in mortality
Can censure 'scape; back-wounding calumny
The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong
Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue?

But who comes here?
Enter ESCALUS, PROVOST, and Officers with
MISTRESS OVERDONE.

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p: Go; away with her to prison!

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
Escal.
sp.p:
Double and treble admonition, and
still forfeit
in the same kind! This would
make mercy swear
and play the tyrant.

sp.speaker: Prov.
sp.p:
A bawd of eleven years' continuance,
may it
please your honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs Ov.
sp.p:
My lord, this is one Lucio's information
against
me. Mistress Kate Keepdown
was with child by
him in the duke's time; he
promised her marriage: his
child is a year and
a quarter old, come Philip and Jacob:
I have
kept it myself; and see how he goes about
to
abuse me!

sp.speaker: Escal.
sp.p:
That fellow is a fellow of much
license: let
him be called before us. Away
with her to prison! Go
to; no more words.
[Exeunt Officers with Mistress Ov.
Provost, my brother
Angelo will
